BE11:16am

Takeover offer at €16 per share EP Global announced its intention to launch a voluntary takeover offer of Metro at €16 per common shares (see the PR here ), in line with the current share price level, which is where we move our TP. Since EP Global took its stake in Metro with options enabling it to reach above 30% of the capital, the speculative angle has been supporting the share price. We valued Metro’s shares at €13, given the risk to the recovery story in Russia and potential additional margin pressure. We therefore consider the €16 per share offer an attractive one. It values Metro on 0.3x 2019 EV/Sales, 6.5x EV/EBITDA, 11.1x EV/EBIT, 14.4x 2019 PE and a 3.4% FCF yield.

red @Foresterwhatever you view of him her, think going a bit too far esp given background of those involved.
Bluesky21 (Sorry I will stop. That night was painfully burned into my mind.)
BE11:17am

EP Global owns 11% of Metro with options to get 21% more. It announced it was launching a voluntary takeover offer on Metro at €16 per common shares and

€13.80 per preferential shares. The offer is in line with Friday’s closing price for ordinary shares and 6% above the preference shares' closing price. Metro’s capital has €5.76bn of ordinary shares and €39m of preference shares.
For the ordinary shares, it is 34% above the share price level before EP Global’s initial investment on 24 August 2018. The offer will be subject to a certain minimum acceptance threshold of all ordinary shares which shall be sufficient in the view of EP Global to secure approval for a domination and P&L transfer agreement with Metro after settlement of the offer.
EP Global has the full support of key shareholder Haniel (which owns 15% of the group) and holds a call option from Ceconomy, amounting to 5% of the capital. EP Global also mentions that:
n it has a clear growth strategy, no intentions to close Metro stores in Germany or to move headquarters from Düsseldorf;
n it does not intend to terminate existing shop agreements and collective bargaining agreements in Germany;
n it supports continued sale process of Metro China unit; and
n the offer itself and its terms and conditions will be set out once the German regulator has approved the publication of the offer document.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

Here's Bernstein:

BE11:19am

What could happen next? We see 3 scenarios:

(1) EP Global bid succeeds at €16. This will probably require the 2 families to be supportive of the bid or the company's board to realise that they are fighting a lost battle and recommend the bid to go ahead

(2) EP Global raises the bid to get the board's approval. The current share price is about 32% above the value the shares traded before EP Global took a stake. There may be further upside to the value, but we would struggle to see much upside beyond €18.

(3) EP Global bid fails and both EP Global and Haniel family are two angry shareholders with a ~15% stake each. In that case the shares would likely go back to the undisturbed share price and fair value of €12.

The fear of the latter scenario will likely focus the minds of shareholders, possibly including the two large ones (Meridian and Beisheim).

JP11:19am

I know little about Metro bar that I shopped in one of them in Karlsruhe. It was decent enough.

11:19 am
BE11:20am

And Olivetree:

BE11:20am

Through acquiring the stakes of Haniel and Cecomony, EPGC will cross the 30% control threshold. By offering a paltry premium to market price, it would appear at first glance that despite reference to lofty acceptance thresholds – this is more an attempt to cross 30% without making a mandatory offer. The main benefit of doing this in a voluntary fashion is that EPGC can choose not to proceed with the Haniel purchase if it decides to, and indeed it may get more acceptances from minorities than a mandatory offer would. With such a quick, and unsurprising, rejection by the target it would appear unlikely that material amounts of stock are tendered into this transaction however – the underlying rationale for the transaction needs to be better understood. To achieve a 75% voting power at an EGM, and thus be able to impose a Domination Agreement, EPGC will likely need a further 32.2% of the entire company to tender, this is some 47% of the minorities left in the company. Although EPGC will argue that Metro’s strong outperformance in 2019 has been thanks to underlying M&A expectations, why such a large block of stock would be expected to agree to a price at such a small premium to market remains unclear. Thus, at first glance this appears more an attempt to cross the 30% level in the most scientific way possible – presumably picking up SOME minority tenders along the way – than a genuine attempt to control 100% of Metro. A better understanding of the true underlying motivations for Friday’s announcement appears needed.

JP11:23am

Here's UBS:

JP11:23am

Sale of 80% equity interest in Carrefour China could drive c.4% EPS accretion
Carrefour has agreed to sell 80% of its equity interest in Carrefour China (c.5% group sales; c.2% group EBITDA), in an all cash transaction, to Suning.com by end of 2019 (subject to competition authorities' approval). The €1.4bn transaction EV represents: 1) €774m equity value; 2) c.€400m operating debt related to shopping cards and 3) €226m for net financial debt and minority interest. We estimate Carrefour China (FY18 €-32m EBIT) was a c.20bps drag on group EBIT margin in FY18 and deconsolidating 80% of the business could be c.4% accretive to EPS.

JP11:23am

Implied EV/sales transaction multiple at 0.38x vs. group EV/sales at 0.26x.
The implied EV/sales multiple for Carrefour China is estimated at c.0.38x/0.27x (inc./ex. shopping card debt), relative to group EV/sales at 0.26x. The anticipated cash proceeds for the transaction is €620m (80% of €774m equity value), subject to a transaction closing adjustment for net financial debt and working capital. The transaction agreement also gives both Carrefour and Suning.com several liquidity windows to sell/buy the remaining 20% in Carrefour China. With lease adjusted net debt/EBITDAR at 1.3x (FY19e), Carrefour's balance sheet seems fairly robust relative to peers, and given this is only the second year into a 5-year turnaround plan, we anticipate that the majority of the cash proceeds will be reinvested back into the remaining business.

11:23 am
JP11:23am

Stub co' P/E trading at c.8.2x; risk/reward skewed to the upside
We'd identified the exit of structurally loss-making segments as one of the key levers in Bompard's turnaround plan. Despite launch of a strategic partnership with tech-leader Tencent early last year to address the deficiency in its omnichannel offering, Carrefour China has struggled to see a recovery in its negative LfLs (FY18: -5.9%; FY17: -5.5%). The divestment of Carrefour China should enable Bompard to further invest in the customer value proposition of the core France business whilst protecting margins and cashflow. Hard work remains to grow Europe and France hypermarket LfLs, but with the turnaround plan continuing apace and a Stub Co' (ex. Brazil, ex. China) P/E estimated at c.8.2x, we see risk-reward firmly skewed to the upside here.

JP11:28am

Selling 80% of Carrefour China at a good price. Carrefour just announced an agreement to sell 80% of its Chinese business in a deal that would value 100% of it with an EV at €1.4bn to Suning.com (retailer with an online to offline model that operates 8,881 stores and is the 3rd largest B2C E-commerce platform). It implies a valuation of 0.4x 2019E EV/Sales, with a 21x EV/EBITDA assuming stable EBITDA in 2019 (12x EBITDA in, in our view, a bullish scenario in which 2019 EBITDA sees a similar margin improvement than in 2018).

JP11:29am

Oh wait, Shore Capital have weighed in:

JP11:29am

China, an Eastern El Dorado for a number of 'Western' domiciled multi-product store based retailers, has become something of a corporate graveyard. A number of grocers have sought to bring their long-standing offline capabilities to this distinctive political economy and market, one where the digital age appears to have arrived as a first base for modern retailing for many shoppers. Alas, despite all the huge potential that the Chinese market seemingly offered, a successful financial way through has rarely, if ever, been found.

And so, within this context, a Carrefour that like Tesco^ (TSCO, Buy) has focused down upon financial returns, cash generated from operations and conservative capital allocation in recent times, has followed its British counterparty in materially diluting its presence in China. Tesco did so some years ago, amidst the corporate recoil that saw it exit Japan, South Korea, Turkey and the USA whilst ceasing further capital commitments to China, where it has a 20% stake in the Vanguard Group, a local player, and India too, where it operates in partnership with Tata/Trent.

11:29 am
JP11:29am

Carrefour has chosen to sell 80% of its equity in Carrefour China to Suning.com. Suning is described as an online-to-offline Chinese company. Whilst admittedly jargon laden the business states that 'by launching logistics services, data services and financial services via the cloud, and through the use of different consumer-facing channels..., Suning delivered a ubiquitous one-stop service experience to its consumers'.

Through this deal Suning gains an 80% interest in Carrefour China's 210 supermarkets and 24 convenience stores (CVS). Despite its digital characterisation above, Suning.com also operates nearly 9000 stores in 700 Chinese cities and is said to run the No.3 B2C e-commerce platform

As to the transaction, well Suning.com is acquiring 80% of a Carrefour China that is said to have an enterprise value of EUR1.4bn; the equity component is reported to be EUR774m, so Carrefour is receiving EUR620m subject to adjustment mechanisms; operating debt in relation to shopping cards amounts to cEUR400m. In FY2018, Carrefour China recorded sales of EUR3.6bn and EBITDA of EUR66m, a 1.8% margin that may explain the exit after 24 years of trying. Future liquidity criteria are set out for the sale of the remaining 20% of Carrefour's stake, which leads us to anticipate a full exit in time.

JP11:29am

The material expansion of major Western groups into Asia, and Central Europe for that matter, represented a very different time for perceived corporate opportunity. The rise of the internet has been a key change factor changing the world since, just as has the inability of the prime movers to effectively internationalise whilst retaining a firm focus on their respective motherships. Additionally, understanding the reality of retailing on the ground in China has proved to be a hard lesson.

Indeed, hard and expensive lessons have been learnt by many about how to effectively take multi-brand retail propositions to new markets. Accordingly, 25 years since Carrefour and Tesco embarked upon their globetrotting, they now only compete in Poland, where we would not be surprised to see the latter exit in time, geographic operational complementarity that now permits collaboration through their buying agreement. In the meantime, their has been much planning, much hope, much capital expenditure but largely derisory returns.

Focus has its merits and the returns thresholds from diversification should be high. Accordingly, we imagine Carrefour shareholders will welcome this decision, just as Tesco's owners are happier with management's current approach, set out in the recent Capital Markets Day.

BornCynic Anything on PZ Cussons please JP?

11:35 am
BE11:35am

..... my point was that, if they're saying they're happy at 60-74% that doesn't suggest a necessity to trigger said clause.

BE11:35am

Back to Olivetree.

BE11:36am

As per the announcement, the offer will be subject to a minimum acceptance threshold which will be sufficient in the view of the Bidder to secure approval of a domination and profit and loss transfer agreement. Obviously this means that the bidder must be able to vote through the domination agreement at a Metro EGM with a motion requiring 75% of acceptances. Knowing that EPGC controls 31.5% (including its irrevocables) means that it must attract sufficient amounts of minorities to boost this to 75% of whatever share capital would turn up to such an EGM. Fig 6 shows that if 100% of the company turned up, EPGC would need the support of a further 43.5% of the company (63.5% of all the minorities). This falls to 32.2% (47% of all minorities) if we model a turnout of 78%, seen at this year’s AGM.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

BE11:37am

Obviously the Haniel irrevocable of 15.2% is included in the acceptance level requirement. It would seem therefore logical that EPGC will set an acceptance level of 58.7% (call it 60%) upfront. This will give them 75% once the Haniel stock is tendered upon the conservative assumption that 100% of the register will attend the meeting.

Even if we assume a more aggressive 78% turnout, the more pertinent question would be why nearly half the remaining minorities of Metro will tender into an offer pitched at just 2% premium to Friday’s close.

BE11:37am

But we're probably just arguing about angels on the heads of pins now. Let's move on.

BE11:41am

Exane -- the best on Dixons historically -- said this late last week.

BE11:42am

In December the company’s strategic update suggested flat profits for several years. Yesterday, market conditions caused management to go harder and deeper at the transformation, promising faster cost cutting but also guiding to a UK Mobile loss in FY20e. This reduces our Apr-20e EPS by 30%. The impact on cashflow is smaller, and as a result our DCF-derived target price falls by a more modest 10% to 135p. Earnings may be at a trough, but we believe execution will have to be flawless with profit margins at 2% and strong external headwinds blowing. We remain Neutral.

red so folks that are landlords to dikos bad news
11:42 am
BE11:42am

Carphone Warehouse’s profits in Apr-20e will be supported by GBP60m from renegotiating its volume commitments to the networks operators. Nevertheless management expects UK Mobile profits to fall from GBP9m in Apr-19 to a c.GBP 90m loss. Returning to break-even by FY Apr-22e looks possible, helped by GBP100m of cost savings and the total roll-off of volume commitments. Profit growth beyond is plausible, although it is unclear what the Carphone model, ‘unconstrained’ by the networks, will look like. Nevertheless, the main positive from Thursday’s results is that the leg down at Carphone feared by investors has now happened, but with smaller cash implications.

red id agree with that. need to see things changing on the paperwork front first
JP11:43am

UBS also pointed out the struggling phone segment:

JP11:43am

FY20 PBT guidance much lower than expected at £210mPBT guidance for FY20 effectively splits the business into two: an Electricals business showing modest growth and making c£325m EBIT, and a UK Mobile business losing £90m and potentially moving into profit in FY22. Clearly they should be valued differently, but the valuation of the stock largely comes down to the respective PE multiples. UK electricals is the only multi-channel specialist in the market, and we assume 8x. Nordic is the clear market leader with longer term strategic value. We take 11x here, with Greece at 12x. We value Mobile at -£200m, the likely worst case cumulative losses. Adjusting for net debt (c£265m), the pension deficit (£579m) and the cash release from the mobile debtor book (c£500m) and we generate a fair value of 200p, down from a prior value of 220p.

11:43 am
JP11:43am

Is guidance credible?Uncertainty mainly relates to the UK activities. Nordic has a strong track record and the business model (low gross margin, low EBIT margin, steady market share growth) makes life difficult to existing and potential competitors. Greece is smaller but in a strong position after the credit crunch market shakeout. Mobile guidance of eventual break even or better seems possible given that onerous volume targets will fall away over the next 18 months, management sees £100m of cost savings in the division, and the average lease length is 2.2 years. UK Electricals may be more problematic given Brexit risks and no obvious signs of capacity exit, but the flip side is that no-one seems to want a price war and there are also substantial cost savings here

JP11:43am

Big hit to FY20 estimate, more limited thereafterOur FY20 EPS estimate falls by one third, although the gap declines as Mobile losses abate. Longer term, management guidance of 3.5% group EBIT margin is intact, but will be delivered in FY23 not FY24. Guidance of £1bn cumulative cash flow over the plan is also unchanged. Guidance for FY22 PBT is over £300m (UBSe now £314m).Valuation: Buy, Price Target 200p (from 220p)As seen from the 30% intra-day swing on results day, there are major uncertainties relating to achievability of guidance and the right valuation to apply. As outlined above, we stick with SOP, which falls given the different mix of profit streams.

JP11:44am

Mobile valued at err...negative £200m.

Bluesky21 https://news.efinancialcareers.com/uk-en/270553/odey-earl-of-glamorgan-robert-somerset
Bluesky21 He is really not a good indicator of anything
red bt can come to poland, there is certainly not a glut here.
BE11:49am

We have viewed BT as one of the least attractive of European telcos (pls see our Outlook 2019 stock preferences) given low levels of fibre deployment and the less advanced state of convergence competition in the U.K. (vs other markets). However
given our view that the european telcos sector is cheap which when combined with DB’s absolute (rather than relative) recommendation system, we had ranked the stock at Hold (after three years at Sell).

We continue to view BT as an underperformer as the U.K. catches up with convergence and fibre build and are concerned that a number of near-term factors will trigger a higher risk premium on BT shares. These include: the funding of more alt-FTTH projects, the associated risk of lower wholesale revenues at Openreach, higher capex, and a dividend cut which we now assume will happen from next year.

Whilst the eventual impact of alt-FTTH build will take years, we are concerned that the ‘free’ ISPs of Sky and TalkTalk (together combined 40% retail broadband share) will pre-commit to material alt-FTTH build projects (including some of their own) inorder to facilitate infrastructure competition and lower wholesale rates for FTTH

11:49 am
BE11:49am

Whilst there is much work to be done actually building fibre, organising an efficient customer switching process (to FTTP) and educating customers as to the benefits of full fibre, we now believe that capital supply and ambition are less of an impediment to alt-FTTH build and that the industry has reached a collective 'tipping point' towards full fibre deployment. BT/Openreach has responded with an accelerated build programme and wholesale volume discounts and will remain the UK’s largest infrastructure operator, though with potentially lower profitability than presently anticipated.

BE11:49am

We cut our FY22 Normalised FCF expectations by 12% due to a combination of lower EBITDA and higher capex (both could deteriorate further if fibre build by BT is accelerated and/or alt-FTTH roll-out plans prove successful). To avoid continued strain on BT's balance sheet (we see little relief on the pension front given lower interest rates globally) we now anticipate a cut of BT's dividend to 10.3p (5.0% yield) from FY21.

BE11:50am

(Still don't understand why we need FTTH. Copper's fine. Joseph Lechleider fixed it.)

JP11:52am

Truth be told, we had to double check the fact that Alphabet
has materially underperformed the S&P 500 over the past
year. Much of this weakness has been recent. With
disappointing 1Q 2019 earnings and concerns around U.S.
antitrust action, Alphabet’s stock price has dropped -13%
from a recent peak at the end of April.

11:53 am
JP11:53am

our analysis of Google’s own Economic Impact
reports suggests that U.S. search revenue growth has been
decelerating from 2016 and fell by -1,000 bps to +18% in
2018. If this is indeed the case, a surge in ad growth at
YouTube has helped mask that deceleration. Without
proper granular disclosure, we are assuming that the
deceleration in 1Q 2019 reflected continuing deceleration in
Search that wasn’t offset by YouTube.

JP11:53am

The focus on the top-line ignores the continued margin
erosion at Alphabet as the company continues to invest in
growth in Hardware and GCP. We forecast -200 bps of
margin erosion in 2019 followed by flattish margins in
2020 and beyond. Further weakness in ad growth may
actually force the company to accelerate investment
spending in other growth initiatives.

JP11:53am

11:54 am
JP11:54am

Also, news that the Department of Justice will be probing Alphabet for antitrust issues has further weighed on the stock over the past few weeks. However, we still believe antitrust action to break up the digital platforms is unlikely. The DOJ will need to prove evidence of consumer harm to get antitrust action through the U.S. courts. Yet, even if Alphabet were to be broken up, it may actually be value accretive as the market may finally gain visibility into YouTube or Cloud financials. Meanwhile, Other Bets like Verily and Waymo may see the light of day and be assigned value rather than just having their losses lumped into the overall conglomerate multiple applied to Alphabet as a whole. So, we do not believe antitrust is the primary concern for Alphabet’s stock. Instead, attention should be paid to the health of its underlying business, but we will have to wait for another quarter of results before concluding that there are deeper issues at play here. This stance is in contrast to our view on Facebook where we see revenue stability thanks to the incremental ad volume from Stories.

JP11:54am

BE12:01pm

Bakkavor has faced unprecedented headwinds… In February 2018 Bakkavor’s CEO referred to “unprecedented” input cost pressures facing the UK fresh prepared food industry. A tightening labour market, rapidly rising raw material costs and a weak sterling presented an extremely challenging environment for Bakkavor. As we look ahead to 2H19 and 2020, a softer raw material outlook is making us feel less bearish. While the picture hasn’t turned positive for the company, the more predictable risks may be behind us.

1966AndAllThat @BE how come youtube loss making ? Is it infrastructure costs ? thought its advertising would be attractive as hard to avoid preroll and inroll ads compared to ads on search. (dont think i click a google ad more than once a month and usually by accident or more likely because I dislike the company advertising but need to deal with them)
BE12:02pm

...and is not out of the woods yet. Bakkavor still faces steep challenges. We have limited visibility on when the UK consumer environment will improve and potential disruption from exiting the EU remains an overhang risk. Bakkavor sources 37% of its raw materials from the EU (ex UK) and around 50% of its labour force is made up of EU nationals, making it fairly exposed to the uncertainties of Brexit, such as the potential impact of import tariffs, short term supply chain disruption and tighter immigration controls.Poor cash trajectory but relief ahead.

12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

We forecast £15mn 19e FCF, a third consecutive year of contraction. This won't cover 2019 dividend on our numbers and at 2.1x leverage, cash is increasingly in focus. Amidst ongoing slow growth we do expect relief beyond 2019 as guidance is for reduced capex of 3.5% of sales 2020+ releasing ~£130mn of cash over 2020-23e. Sustained slow volumes will put increasing pressure on profitability as Bakkavor needs to run facilities at high capacity to break even, however near term we see this cash release dynamic as supportive to valuation. We still think elevated capex is required to grow rapidly and ahead of the market, limiting upside in the event of category acceleration.We are still below guidance and consensus. We remain cautious on margin delivery this year and expect underlying market growth to remain soft in the near term. We forecast 1.2% LFL in 1H19, 5.7% in 2H19 and 4.0% in 20. For earnings we expect 13.2p '19e, 13.3p '20e and 14.1p '21e, putting us ~5% below 2021 consensus EPS. We increase our PT from 140p to 145p reflecting a 6M roll forward to June 2020 and a 2-3% change to earnings due to contract wins and acquisitions.
